Rhett having the address to shield his own gross prevarications by retorting upon Wise, and charging upon him the loss of the battle by bad management— Evans of Maine then took the floor, and another wrangle of an hour succeeded, in which Chapman of Alabama with his gang at his heals, struggled to filch the floor from Evans; but did not succeed— He made his speech and finally moved that the members of the House of Representatives present advised and requested the Speaker to administer the Oath to the five commissioned gentlemen from New-Jersey— Petrikin sputtered against this form of the question because it did not recognize the members present as a House. But his gang deserted him; and the question was put upon Evans’s Motion— There was a call of the House— Three couple paired off. Evans’s motion was lost by yeas and nays 112 to 116.— The majority being constituted by Pickens, Rhett, Griffin, Holmes, Sumpter of South Carolina and Charles Shepard of North-Carolina— These same men effected the election of Hunter as Speaker; a flying squadron who subsist by passing from side to side with the perpetual prostration of all honest principle. Hoffman immediately offered a Resolution to adopt the rules of the last Congress with the exception of the 11th. the vote viva voce. Bell moved an amendment to except also the 44th. and 45th. rules, about the previous Question— An angry debate, and sharp personalities ensued till 9 in the evening, when the House adjourned by yeas and nays 117 to 107.
21. V:30. Saturday

Miss Pearce came this morning and mentioned that she had called upon Mr Taliaferro, but found that he entertained a very different opinion concerning the merit of her claim from that of Mr Burges— She said she had been advised to go to Mr Joseph Nourse for information in support of it, and I advised her to go, supposing that Mr Nourse may have some knowledge concerning it— Mr Charles W. James of Cincinnati Ohio, a collector and general agent for eastern and western publishers and merchants came and claimed old acquaintance and correspondence of which I had no recollection.— But his object was to request me to send him congressional documents during the Session, complaining that the whigs of Cincinnati never received any from the representative of that place Dr Duncan— At the House the question came up on Hoffman’s motion to adopt the rules of the last House of Representatives with the exception of the 11th. which prescribes that the officers of the House shall be chosen viva voce— Bell had withdrawn his motion to except also the rules relating to the previous question— Bell made a warm and eloquent Speech to defend himself against the attack of Pickens upon him last Evening and he declaimed forcibly against the executive influence upon the house; a theme upon which Pickens used to rave like a maniac; and upon which he now roars like a sucking dove. The question of voting by ballot or viva voce was discussed by sundry stump Orators, to the corps of which Caleb Cushing now acceded— Hoffman’s exception was struck out, and the rules were adopted in a mass— The House then proceeded to elect the Clerk, and Hugh A. Garland received 118 votes, Matthew St. Clair Clark 105. and R. C. Mason nominated by Hopkins of Virginia 8—if the five New Jerseymen had voted there would have been a tie, and Garland would not have been chosen— He stands self-elected, by the baseness of his treachery to his trust.— He carried his election by the South-Carolinians.— The next Officer to be chosen was the Serjeant at arms— The whigs had determined in Caucus to vote for William Jones late Postmaster in this City, whose only claim was that he had been turned out of the Post Office last Spring— They had got Griffin of South-Carolina to nominate him— Mitchell of New-York came just before my name was called, and said they had agreed to vote for Jones— I knew of no misconduct of Dorsey, who was the Serjeant at Arms of the last House, and I told Mitchell I would vote for no man nominated by Griffin— I voted for Dorsey—so did Cushing; but came to me shortly after, and said he had voted so because I did; but Wise had been to him and remonstrated because he said Dorsey, used his office for electioneering— Cushing withdrew or changed his vote, but Dorsey was chosentoEverett then moved to postpone the further choice of Officers, for the purpose of sending a Message to the Senate announcing that the House of Representatives had chosen Robert M. T. Hunter for their Speaker, and were ready to proceed to business; and then for the appointment of a Committee on the part of the House to join with a Committee of the Senate to inform the President that both Houses are assembled and ready to receive Communications from him— Carried and adjourned at 6. P.M.
22. IV:30. Sunday.

Snow in the Night, and through the greatest part of this day, at least a foot and a half deep—occasionally turning to sleet and rain, with a moderate gale, and very little drifting of the Snow.— I went at 11 A.M. to the Presbyterian Church, and found there Mr M’Lellan, Mr Hand; three other men, and five boys— All together not enough, including myself to make a petit jury. After waiting a reasonable time for the preacher, who did not appear, I came home and read Gleig’s introduction to the history of the Bible. There was no afternoon Church Bell, and I had a day of bodily repose— Of mental repose I can enjoy none, while witnessing the wrong that I cannot prevent, and suffering at once from the injustice of man, and the chastising hand of Heaven— Disease, bereavement, afflictions not to be named, and the temptations of the adversary to conclude with Brutus that virtue is but a name— Yet there is in Providence a vis medicatrix—a healing, repairing, redeeming hand— Let me never despair of its power—never be weary of well doing— Perhaps the severest trial of righteousness is the patient Fortitude which endures without yielding to the perverseness of mankind— In adversity, consider— I employed part of this day in preparing for the presentation of Petitions, and in assorting papers. Upon that most vexatious and portentous subject of Slavery and the Slave-trade, I am yet to fix upon the course which it will be my duty to pursue— I see clearly that it is not for me to volunteer in bringing it forward; and as clearly that it will be impossible for me to steer clear of it altogether.— It will be forced upon me— It will not be for me in walking to direct my steps—may they be directed from above! I have received two very extraordinary Letters from N. P. Trist, Consul of the United States at the Havana who is charged with direct and official participation in the African Slave-trade, in which Letters he not only urges me to take up and bring forward this subject in Congress, but insists that I am the man of all others who ought to do it— And these Letters he makes private and confidential, though he never had any private or personal intercourse with me— His object is to gull me with flattery—and to secure impunity to himself, by the exhibition to the South of me as his accuser.— His wishes are at once the evidence of his guilt, and the counterpart of my duty— I made a partial assortment of my papers, and have two Letters from Lewis and Pierce of Brooklyn, long island, both dated from 16th. instt. one enclosing a Letter to the Commissioner of Pensions and three additional documents in support of the claim of widow Dinah Benson to a pension under the act of 7. July 1838— The other with a similar Letter to the Commissioner James L. Edwards and three documents in support of the Pension claim of widow Sarah Lennington, under the same act.— General Scott was without the bar of the House of Representatives on Friday and Mr Vandenhoff the Tragedian who was introduced to me, and greeted me, as an admirer of Shakespear— There were also introduced to me, two members one of them, Speaker of the Assembly of the Island of Barbados.
23. V:15. Monday

The Revd F. W. Boyd called on me this morning, and informed me of his wish to receive the appointment of chaplain to the House of Representatives— He said he had made no solicitation among the members, with scarcely any of whom he had any personal acquaintance, and besides which it was an expedient to which he should not willingly resort— I told him I had received a printed circular from an episcopal clergyman named Wilmer, and a recommendation of a presbyterian named Danforth— That I supposed Mr Slicer the chaplain of the last house would again be a candidate, and that I had heard a Mr Cookman a Methodist Minister would also be upon the list.— All this he knew before but said he understood Mr Cookman was a candidate only for the chaplaincy of the Senate— I told Mr Boyd, I should cheerfully vote for him; Albert Smith of Maine came, to me in the House and told me he should nominate him, as he belonged to a very respectable family at Portland, his near neighbours— The business of the day was to chuse a door keeper; under door keeper, Post-master and printer— H Everett from the joint Committee to wait on the President reported that he had informed them, he would send to both Houses of Congress a Message in writing at 12. O’Clock to-morrow— The usual Message of Meeting was received from the Senate, and another— For Door keeper of the house; there was a party strike Joseph Follansbee, the Door keeper of the last House happens to be a New-England man, and no partizan— A shark by the name of Dow, wanted his place; but the could not carry it— The Carolinians voted for Follansbee and he had 130 votes, Dow 73. and a man named Houston 15. The under door keeper John W. Hunter, and the Post-master M’Cormick were chosen by Resolution, without nominal call— But the lug was for the printer— Stanly moved a Resolution that the printing should be done by contract to the lowest bidder— Anderson of Kentucky moved an amendment which Stanly accepted to suspend the execution of the order of last Saturday for the election of a printer; and raise a Committee to cheapen the public printing and separate it from the Newspaper press— Then followed a snarling debate of five hours; questions, of order innumerable, motions to lay on the table, previous questions, decisions of the Chair and an appeal from one of them by Cave Johnson— Crimination and recrimination in abundance on the score of economy.— A call for the reading of a jesiutical report of M’Kay at the last Session—made to the House but never read, with Resolutions which M’Kay for a long time could not find, but which were at length produced— About 6. O’Clock the House adjourned—having proceeded no further than the nomination of Blair and Rives, by Smith of Maine— I rode home in a hack, leaving Mr Taliaferro at his lodgings— Our man Jeremy Leary is ill with the Dysentery—
24. V.30 Tuesday

The Snow makes the roads and Streets almost impracticable, and the railway communication with Baltimore was interrupted from Sunday Morning till this Evening— Immediately after the reading of the Journal at the House, the President’s Message was delivered by his SonIt took the Clerk upwards of an hour and a half to deliver it— The picture of the condition of the nation is of mingled light and shade— Its foreign affairs in general are highly prosperous.— The rest is a dissertation upon political-economy, Banks, Currency, Exchange, Gold and Silver, and an Independent Treasury with the Specie clause.— It is understood that this measure will now be carried— The mismanagement of the Banks, and above all the suspension of specie payment by the Pennsylvania Bank of the United States, and most of the Banks of Philadelphia, and South and West of that City, have excited the hatred and indignation of the people, against those institutions to such an extent that the faction opposed to them have them at their mercy— The annual report of the Secretary of the Treasury on the finances, and several other Treasury reports, were also presented to the House— There was some discussion as to the number of copies of the Message to be printed with and without the documents.— They were finally ordered to be printed under the direction of the Clerk, and the remainder of the day was consumed in wrangling about the election of a Printer— Dawson moved to postpone till the 1st. of February the election of the Printer, and in the meantime to appoint a Committee to enquire and report whether the expence of the public printing cannot be reduced— Hence a debate of altercation and mutual reproach in which the principal Speakers were Dawson, Sampson Mason, Bond, and Rice Garland on one side, and Vanderpoel and Bynum on the other— Charges of insincerity of hypocrisy and of duplicity were bandied to and fro without stint or restraint— The journals of the House at the three Sessions of the last Congress were ransacked for lists of yeas and nays, and the names of the voters were read over by Vanderpoel and Bynum— In the midst of his most furious vociferation Vanderpoel brought down a shout of laughter upon himself by reading a list of his own party as voting for a resolution, which Rice Garland, rectified by shewing that their vote was for striking it out. And thus time wasted away till Giddings of Ohio took the floor— Various attempts to adjourn had been made with out success till Campbell of South-Carolina moved that when the House should adjourn it should be till Friday— Carried by yeas and nays 8 to 8 After which about 7. O’Clock the motion to adjourn was carried by yeas and naystoI met Thomas coming up in the Capitol yard; and with his assistance walked home— I found Mr Cutts and his daughter at our house. They soon went away, and the remainder of the Evening I passed in the rocking Chair, at my chambers fire side—too much exhausted for labour—
25. V:15. Christmas— Wednesday

Of the merriment of Christmas, we had none. All around us is mourning and sorrow; and melancholy and gloom. Yet are we in the enjoyment of numberless blessings; dispended by a merciful and beneficent Providence, for which my heart ought to overflow with gratitude to God— I walked to Gadsby’s Hotel, to visit Mr Lawrence; but he went off this morning to New-York— I saw Mr Grainger and his daughter who lodge at the same house— Mr Wise was also there on a visit— Called on my return home at Mr Barnard’s lodgings but he was gone out.— I received this day a fresh Letter from Lewis and Pierce of Brooklyn of the 18th. instt. with an enclosure to the Commissioner of Pensions Edwards and a document in support of a claim to a revolutionary pension of Francis Concklin under the act of 7. June 1832— And I had before received from them a Letter of the 8th. instt. with an enclosure to Mr Edwards and Documents in support of the Pension-claim of Phebe Reeve, widow of William Clark— Mrs Smith went and dined with her husband at the prison— After dinner I received from Gales and Seaton the report of my Speech in the House, last Friday, taken in two parts, the first by Stansbury and the second by H. G. Wheeler, the two best Reporters who attend upon the House— The report of Stansbury is until I was interrupted by Frank Thomas’s notable question of order; and Wheeler’s is from the time when I resumed till I closed— I revised all Stansbury’s report and part of Wheeler’s—both are good; but both omit the desperate struggle to take the floor from me before I began, and the infamous attempt of Thomas to put me down in the midst of my discourse— These were really the most interesting incidents of the day; and a true report of them would be much more valuable than that of my Speech. This was not what it ought to have been; nor was it satisfactory to myself— In the New-Jersey case, the popular interest is all on our side of the question; and the popular favour is on the other— I received this afternoon from James F. Otis a Newspaper published at New-York called Brother Jonathan, in which is printed, announced as from the original manuscript, a poem by me called the Vision, written in 1789. or 1790 while I was a student at the Law in the Office of Theophilus Parsons at Newbury-Port. It is nearly fifty years since I had seen this effusion of my early love; and on reading it now the first impression upon my mind is that I have never since written anything equal to it— But I had no copy of it myself, and knew not that a copy of it existed in the world.— My next feeling was curiosity to know whence the publication now came, and through whose hands the manuscript has passed. This I suppose I can ascertain. I received this afternoon a note from Mrs Benjamin Ogle-Tayloe, inviting me to a small tea party this Evening to which I went— I met there Mr Vandenhoff the Tragedian with his daughter and Son—Mr and Mrs Barnard Messrs. King of Georgia, and Jenifer of Maryland members of the House of Representatives, Miss Mary E. E. Cutts, Mr King the Painter and others unknown— Conversation on Shakespear—
26. V:30 Thursday.

Morning visit from Mr Johnson, and Giusta was here twice— I gave him a check on the Washington Bank for Montandon, who procured for me during the recess of Congress a Hogshead of Claret wine— A person by the name of Walker, brought a pamphlet the first number of a History of the Presbyterian Church in the United States, by a Clergyman of Virginia— He said there were to be two numbers more, and I told him, if I took it at all, I would wait till the work shall be completed.— Walter Hellen took tea here, and Mary-Louisa dined at Mrs. Hellen’s— Before dinner I visited President Van Buren, and while I was there, the Vice-President Richard M. Johnson came in with another Kentuckian whom I did not know— Coll. Richard M, whose Vice-Presidential Chair, it is said is to be gently drawn from under him at the next Presidential election appeared much elated at his success in effecting his passage over the snow-choked mountains, so as to reach this city the evening before last.— He thought it a fair parallel to Napoleon’s passage over the Alps— It cost him fifty dollars for extra carriage hire; an inflexible determination to achieve, what all the Stage drivers and Inn-holders pronounced impossible; and sundry bumps in the head, having been twice overset— Mr Van Buren is growing inordinately fat— His son Abraham lately returned from England was with him— I then went to the Pension Office where I found Dr Crump, officiating in the place of the Commissioner James L. Edwards—and I left with him the four Letters from Lewis and Pierce to Mr Edwards, and the documents on the Pension-claims of widows Dinah Benson, Sarah Lennington, and Phebe Reeve, and that of Francis Conklin— Dr Crump said he would report to me on all these cases, and asked if I knew these young men Lewis and Pierce— I told him that Mr Pierce had visited me at my residence since the last Session of Congress.— That he was the Son of an old friend of mine Dr John Pierce of Brookline, a Clergyman inferior in respectability to no man in this Union— That Lewis and Pierce were agents I suppose for all pension claimants who would employ them— I had not the slightest reason for doubting their integrity— They had invoked my assistance in numerous cases last winter— I had cheerfully given it; and should continue so to do, at the present Session, as often as it should be required by them. I called at the Navy Department and gave Mr Paulding the Secretary, a Letter for Midshipman John Quincy Adams, from his Sister Elizabeth— He is in the John Adams on the East India station. At the Bounty Land-Office I left with Mr Gordon the papers and enquiries of Dijah Bowen, concerning the claim of Pierre Gédéon, enlisted at New-Orleans in 1815 in the Legion of Franks upon which Mr Gordon promised me a Report.
27. V:15. Friday

Mrs Telfair, the Sister of Miss Elizabeth Pierce, was here this morning to speak about their claim— She said they had been yesterday to Georgetown, and had seen Mr Joseph Nourse, who had advised them to have a particular search made at the Treasury by an agent of their own, and she said Mr Hawley the Minister had recommended to them Mr Causten; of whom she asked my opinion— I said I was not sufficiently acquainted with him to recommend him; but had no reason for dissuading them from employing him— I had received a Letter of remonstrance from Minott Thayer against the apprehended removal of Asa French as Post-master at Braintree, and the establishment of two Post-Offices there each with a Postmaster and an assistant— Also a Letter from Benjamin Ellis, and four others at Carver with copies of two petitions to the Postmaster General, against the removal of the South Post-Office in that town, to a more northerly location— I took them to the Postmaster General Amos Kendall, and read to him the Letter from Mr Thayer, and one of the Petitions from Carver— After enquiry of the chief Clerk, Kendall told me that the application from Braintree had been made about a year ago—but that nothing had been done; and nothing was intended to be done concerning it— I requested that if it should be taken up for consideration, I might have notice of it; which he said I should. And as to the case at Carver he said it was not the intention of the Department that there should be any change in the location of the Post-Office: and he would see to have it so effected— I called at Major Nourse’s Office, then at the Bank of Washington, and at the National Intelligencer Office, where I left the revised report of my Speech of the 20th. on the New Jersey election case— The House had been ten minutes in Session when I reached the Hall— A Letter from Charles F. Mercer to the Speaker announcing his resignation of his Seat had been read— A Resolution for the appointment of the standing Committees had been adopted—a continuation of the old rules till the 10th. of January had been agreed upon—and there was a negotiation on foot for an immediate adjournment which failed— A concurrent resolution had been received from the Senate for the appointment of Chaplains which had been concurred in without debate— Cooper of Georgia prevailed first upon D. A. Lewis and then upon Crabb to move a reconsideration, and there was an hour and a half consumed in discussing the question whether the house would chuse a chaplain— Hopkins finally moved the previous question, and the reconsideration was refused by yeas and nays 12 toI gave notice that I would next Monday ask leave to introduce a Bill for the disposal of the Smithsonian bequest fund.— I went to the Speaker’s chair and told him that my Bill was in substance that which had been unanimously reported by the Committee of the House at the last Session, and that I should move its reference to a select Committee now— He asked me to name to him members whom I should wish to have on the Committee— The House got into a snarl about the numbers of the President’s Message to be printed and finally upon a motion of reconsideration by Waddy Thompson between 3 and 4. adjourned.
28. VI:15. Saturday.

Rain, snow, sleet, a continual gale, and streets almost impassable— The only sally from the house that I made was to return by card the visit of Mr Levi Woodbury.— The day was not so industriously nor so effectively employed as it should have been— I answered the Letters of Minott Thayer and of Benjamin Ellis and others concerning the Post-Offices at Braintree and at Carver— I wrote to Mr James F. Otis of New-York, Editor of the Brother Jonathan requesting him to give notice to the public, that the publication in that paper of my Vision was made without my knowledge or consent; and that I disclaimed all the initial Letters of names in the notes,—correcting the date of the composition of the poem; published as of 1792 but really of 1789 or the first part of 1790. and enquiring how and from whom he obtained possession of the manuscript.— It is republished as a literary curiosity in Clapp’s Evening Gazette of the 21st. instt. at Boston— It is a fair specimen of what I would have been if I could—as a Poet— I have never surpassed it— My summit-level as a Statesman, Orator, Philosopher and Proser is of about the same elevation— I leave nothing to live after me, but aims beyond my means, and principles too pure for the age in which I have lived.— I answered also a Letter from Sherlock S. Gregory, and send him back one of his crazy petitions about the lost tribes of Israel, Indians and Negroes.— I received a Letter from the Secretary of the Navy J. K. Paulding, enclosing an extract of a despatch form Commodore George C. Read Commander of the East-India Squadron dated Macao Roads 10. June 1839. and announcing that the Dysentery was in the Squadron, and that the sick list numbered more than 90. and was increasing. A Letter from A. W. Thayer of Philadelphia: enclosing a newspaper puff of a Lecture by Judge Conrad, slanderous upon the first settlers of Virginia, and the Plymouth Pilgrims, to monopolize all the glory of humanity to the Indians for Penn and his Quakers— And Mr Thayer urges me to enter the list of controversy, as the champion of the pilgrims against judge Conrad. A Letter from Benjamin Hallowell, President of the Alexandria Lyceum; inviting me to deliver a Lecture before them between this and the 4th. of next April— A Letter from Freeman Hunt Editor of the Merchants Magazine, a monthly periodical published at New-York, earnestly soliciting an Article from me for that work— A Letter from J. B. Pleasants, a Quaker, dated Gould’s Branch 23. December, enclosing a long Letter to Noe Webster, about an Article in the National Intelligencer of the 10th. instt. concerning the English Translation of the Bible— I cannot tell what this honest quaker, would be at— And he appears to know as little himself.— A Letter from George L. Curry President of the Boston, Mechanic Apprentices Library Association, requesting for the disposal of the Institution, a copy of the address to its members with which I concluded my Lectures on the Smithsonian bequest— A Letter from Frederic Smith Amoskeag New Hampshire, and one from William H Cobbs, Boston, asking for Autographs— A specimen of one idle day’s correspondence.
29— VI.30. Sunday

Heard Mr Wood, morning and afternoon—a Christmas Sermon, from a Presbyterian preacher. His morning text was Luke 2.10. [“]And the angel said unto them, Fear not; for behold, I bring you good tidings of great joy, which shall be to all people. 11. For unto you is born this day; in the city of David, a Saviour, which is Christ the Lord.”— The afternoon text was from 1. Timothy 3.16—“God was manifest in the flesh—” The auditory consisted of less than fifty persons and the Discourse was not equal to the theme. The occurrences at the birth of Jesus are partly facts of common occurrence and partly miraculous to the severest trial of faith— A carpenter and his wife going to be taxed as tributary slaves to Augustus Caesar, the woman falls in labour in the stable of an Inn—the child is born, and laid in a manger— They lived at Nazareth a mean and dispised town of Judea—they were going on foot to Jerusalem, and the child was born at Bethlehem a small village a few miles distant from that place. In the compass of human existence can any thing more lowly, without dishonour be imagined as high and low are estimated in the world? Yet this event is announced by an Angel from Heaven to a few shepherds watching their flocks by night in that neighbourhood— The heavenly host with shouts of exultation proclaim to these Shepherds, the infant laid in the manger to be the long promised Messiah—the anointed—the Saviour—and this connects him with all the predictions and all the promises of the antient Covenant; at least from the time of Abraham. Nothing can be more natural or credible than the historical part of the story; but why this preternatural angelic communication to a few solitary shepherds which when related by themselves was evidently not believed? Here is a subject for eloquence of the highest order—for pathos—for imagination—for logical argument—for all the intellect of Paul, and all the extatic fervour of the beloved Apostle— Mr Wood was cold, and tame, and presbyterian— I went after dinner to St John’s Church but it was half an hour too soon, and there was nobody there I read part of the first chapter of Gleig’s History of the Bible and was not very well satisfied with that— It is not a History of the Book, but the History of the Events recorded in the Book; and has the failing of every attempt to bring those events within the bounds of historical credibility—to explain the miraculous by the operation of the ordinary Laws of Nature to which it is a perpetual exception— In the Richmond Whig, I find my Letter ofFebruary 1839 to J. Hackett on the character of Hamlet, which was first published in the New-York Mirror and then in the National Intelligencer— And in the last Night’s Globe there are garbled extracts from two of my Letters to Ellis Gray Loring on the case of the Africans of the Amistad. Part of the same and other extracts are published by Mr Loring himself, in the Boston Courier of the 26th. I have also a Letter from Mr John M. Patton; requesting a copy of my Eulogy on James Madison for Mr John H. Peyton.
30. V:45. Monday.

In the reading of the journal of this morning the standing Committees of the House were announced. John W. Jones, Chairman of the Ways and Means— Francis W. Pickens of the foreign Affairs; and the whole organization as subservient to the executive administration, as if the appointments had been made in the President’s Cabinet. So much for Mr Robert M. T. Hunter’s independent position.— He has followed the footsteps of his illustrious predecessors, in appointing me chairman of the Committee of Manufactures; a station merely ostensible, and therefore suiting my convenience— I deserve no other, and particularly not to be chairman, or a member of any of the laborious Committees. It was expected that the States would be called this morning for petitions, but Wise moved a suspension of the rules to offer a Resolution—that every abolition petition resolution or paper that should be presented to the house, there should be considered an objection to its reception, and the motion for its reception and the motion should be laid upon the table without debate— The vote for suspending the rules was 109 to 77. not two thirds; whereupon Rice Garland of Louisiana, moved to suspend the rules to offer three long argumentatives resolutions terminating in the same result the rejection of all abolition petitions— I asked if he meant that these Resolutions should be debated; for if the house would allow that I would vote for a suspension of the rules— Garland said he had offered them without consultation with any one— I said I could not trust the House with the previous question, and voted against the suspension of the rules—the vote was 107 to 82— Waddy Thompson then claimed the floor upon his motion to reconsider the vote for printing 20000 copies of the President’s message. Jameson of Missouri made a point of order to take the floor from Thompson; which the Speaker decided against him— He appealed, and the house almost unanimously sustained the decision of the Speaker.— Thompson made his Speech of about an hour a philippic upon the message and the administration, and then withdrew his motion for reconsideration. Duncan of Ohio then offered a Resolution that the five claimants to seats from New Jersey, with the certificate from the Secretary of State should be sworn as Members— Sundry propositions were made to get the case before the Committee of elections, and the Speaker presented a packet of depositions which he had received on the subject— I said the proper course would be to instruct the Committee of elections to enquire and report to the house who were elected members from New-Jersey—and that they have leave to send for persons and papers.— This did not suit the tie majority, who intend to let in the spurious members as they ejected the true ones, without a trial— I introduced my bill concerning the Smithsonian bequest, which was read twice, and referred to a select Committee of nine— The Speaker told me he meant to put Dixon H. Lewis upon the Committee— Adjourned after 3. Mrs Smith dined abroad.
31. VI. Tuesday

Snow and frost. A cold and gloomy day. An hour and a half of the time of the house was consumed in motions to amend the journal, first of yesterday, by striking out the specification of Duncan’s motion that the Speaker should swear the certificate claimants of the New Jersey seats, which the Speaker pronounced out of order—from which decision Duncan appealed and the Speaker’s decision was sustained— The motion to strike out was rejected by yeas and naystoNext by inserting in the journal of last Friday the specification of a motion made by Jameson of Missouri, which the Speaker declared out of order; from which decision Jameson appealed and the Speaker was sustained by the house.— The Speaker said it was too late to move an amendment to the Journal of last Friday, and so has always been the practice; but Jameson appealed to the words of the rule which are not limited, and worried him into the admission of his motion to amend and it was carried by yeas and nays 87 to 85. Coles of Virginia then moved a suspension of the rules to offer the second part of Atherton’s gag-resolution of the 12th. of December 1838. for the exclusion of abolition Petitions.— The vote for suspension of the rules failedtowhereupon Wise moved a suspension of the rules to offer the same resolution which he had proposed to offer yesterday, and said he would make the same motion every day throughout the Session— I objected to it as not in order, but the Speaker decided that it was— Bynum appeared to be very indignant with Wise and advised me to appeal from the Speaker’s decision; but I knew he would be sustained— Wise’s Resolution was losttoAnd then Chinn of Louisiana moved to suspend the rules to offer a Resolution, that all the abolition petitions that may be presented shall be referred to a select Committee the vote upon this wastoshewing a decided majority of the house for referring the petitions, but not a sufficient number to suspend the rules— Smith of Maine and others called sturdily for the Orders of the day; which the Speaker declared to be the calling by States for the presentation of Petitions—but Sergeant moved a suspension of the rules to offer a Resolution that the daily call for petitions, limited by a rule of the house to the first thirty days of the Session should be in force twenty days from this day— Some of the Slaveholders vehemently resisted this, and Bynum, sounded the trumpet for the rights of the South.— Stanly, Jenifer and W. Cost Johnson gave him a severe castigation to which he was exceedingly desirous of replying— But Rice Garland moved the previous question and inflexibly refused to withdraw it— The Rules were suspended and Sergeant’s Resolution was adopted— It was by this time between 3. and 4. O’Clock, and after a struggle to adjourn over till Friday without taking the yeas and nays it was carried.

Day— From 5 till 11 in the morning till 11. I am occupied at home, on the journal yesterday, tending my fire, hearing Mary-Louisa read, Household concerns and breakfast. H.R U S from Noon till 5. P.M— Home and dine— Weary and idle evening till 10 or 11. and then to bed.— I close the year, with a broken, and I hope a contrite Spirit, and grateful resignation to the Will of God—
